item.title: A story with twists and turns: How to control the rotation of the notched stick
item.description: arXiv:2412.04891v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: The notched stick, also known as the Gee-Haw-Whammy-Diddle, is a wooden toy able to convert linear vibration into rotational motion, whose behavior has been intriguing both children and physicists for decades. Here we derive an analytical model of the system, supported by experimental results. We predict the direction of rotation, and explain why the device is so easy to operate, even without fine control of the various parameters. The potential importance of the vertical displacement of the finger exerting the perturbation force is also highlighted. We finally discuss similarities between the mechanical system described here and the optical effect of birefringence.
item.dc:creator: Martin Luttmann, Michel Luttmann

item.title: Linearization of Newton's second law
item.description: arXiv:2412.05036v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: The geometric linearization of nonlinear differential equation is a robust method for the construction of analytic solutions. The method is related to the existence of Lie symmetries which can be used to determine point transformations such that to write the given differential equation in a linear form. In this study we employ another geometric approach and we utilize the Eisenhart lift to geometric linearize the Newtonian system describing the motion of a particle in a line under the application of an autonomous force. Our findings reveal that for the oscillator, the Ermakov potential with or without the oscillator term, and the Morse potential, Newton's second law can be globally expressed in the form of that of a free particle. This study open new directions for the geometric linearization of differential equations via equivalent dynamical systems.
item.dc:creator: Andronikos Paliathanasis

item.title: Electrostatic potential of a uniformly charged disk through Green's theorem
item.description: arXiv:2407.00392v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: All existing derivations of the electrostatic potential of a uniformly charged disk are technically rather involved. In an old and now almost forgotten publication, Duffin and McWhirter proposed a method for calculating the electrostatic potentials of planar bodies by a skillful application of Green's theorem. It is shown that this method significantly simplifies the problem of calculating the electrostatic potential of a uniformly charged disk and makes it an almost trivial task.
item.dc:creator: Alina E. Sagaydak, Zurab K. Silagadze
